abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Development Fund Project for
            Cameroon achieved a marginally satisfactory outcome.
            Institutional development is rated as modest and
            sustainability as uncertain. Although the water supply
            target was achieved, the original concept of the Rural
            Development Fund became untenable under the changed economic
            conditions. The Bank was initially over-optimistic about the
            scope of the operation but the project was later streamlined
            and the major element completed. For most of the
            implementation period, supervision records are missing. Bank
            performance is rated as unsatisfactory. Overall the specific
            objectives of the original project were only partially
            achieved. The Borrower's performance, like the
            Bank's, had its strengths and weaknesses. The
            Government experienced mounting fiscal difficulties as the
            value of the currency rose steadily from 1985 to 1987.
            Counterpart funds were not made available and work was not
            initiated on most of the smaller project components as
            agencies, facing financial stringency, concentrated on their
            core functions. The rural water supply component was much
            delayed. The Bank wished to agree on the principle of cost
            recovery for rural water supply. It took over a year to
            establish a National Water Committee and then over three
            years to elaborate a national beneficiaries'
            participation policy. Implementation of the well drilling
            program was also held up by a procurement dispute. By 1988,
            an agreement was reached to streamline the project. The
            principal lesson learned is that the value of a project by
            project approach is modest when the objective is to change a
            sector wide policy. Other lessons revolved around judging
            the implementation capacity of the Government, consideration
            of macro and sectoral/subsectoral factors, project design
            focuses, and project implementation.
